conclusion: To solve for the mass ratio of block A to block B, analyze the forces acting on both blocks and use the given coefficients of friction.
Block A is on the ground, and block B is in close contact with block A with a horizontal force applied.
The contact surface between A and B is vertical.
The maximum static friction force is equal to the sliding friction force.
Coefficients of kinetic friction are given as μ1 between A and B, and μ2 between A and the ground.
Block B has a horizontal force F applied, normal force NB from block A, frictional force fBA from block A, gravitational force mB g, and normal force NA from the ground.
Block A has normal force NA from the ground, frictional force fA from the ground, normal force NB from block B, and gravitational force mA g.
Since block B is just about to slide down, the frictional force fBA equals the applied horizontal force F.
The maximum static friction force between B and A is fBA = μ1 NB.
Since block A is just about to slip, the frictional force fA equals the normal force NB times μ2.
Relate the normal forces: NA = mB g and NB = mA g.
Substitute NA = mB g and NB = mA g into the equation μ2 NA = μ1 NB.
Cancel out g from both sides to get μ2 mB = μ1 mA.
Solve for the mass ratio mA/mB = μ2/μ1.
The mass ratio of block A to block B is μ2/μ1.
